holidays.name: Hiroshima Day
holidays.description: A solemn day marking the anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, Japan, in 1945 during World War II. It’s observed to remember the tragic loss and to promote peace and nuclear disarmament.
holidays.origin: Commemorates the first use of an atomic bomb in warfare by the United States on August 6, 1945.
holidays.funFact: The mushroom cloud from the bomb was visible over 80,000 feet high — nearly twice the cruising altitude of a commercial airplane!

holidays.name: Fresh Breath Day
holidays.description: Celebrate your pearly whites and mighty mouth by giving your breath a fresh boost! A fun reminder to keep your oral hygiene on point.
holidays.origin: Created by oral care companies to promote dental health awareness and encourage people to floss and brush.
holidays.funFact: Bad breath, officially called halitosis, affects around 25% of people worldwide — so keep flossing to stay fresh!

holidays.name: Happiness Happens Day
holidays.description: A lighthearted day encouraging everyone to stop, smile, and find happiness in the small moments.
holidays.origin: Started in 1999 by Steve Wilson and Karen Brady as a reminder that happiness is a choice and can be found every day.
holidays.funFact: Studies show that smiling—even if forced—can actually improve your mood thanks to the brain’s feedback mechanisms!

holidays.name: National Root Beer Float Day (USA)
holidays.description: Indulge in the classic American summer treat: a scoop of vanilla ice cream floating in a frosty glass of root beer — yum!
holidays.origin: Celebrated in the USA to honor the delicious soda dessert combo that dates back to the late 19th century.
holidays.funFact: Root beer floats were invented by Robert McCay Green in Philadelphia in 1874 when he mixed ice cream and soda for a refreshing drink.
